@LongLastToken @sriramk Fair Q - I think equity in many projects *could* match that- but every project is doing "governance" tokens long vests instead of a fundamental revenue token with realistic vesting.

If US SEC had clarity & trustworthy safe harbor, we'd be so much further ahead on the tech.

@QuanSai @sriramk I agree- too many pop-ups and it makes everything ad optimization & ruins the fun. I'm on record with many P2E criticisms.

But there is a balance where hardos who want more should be able to pay more to get stuff, and that money can fund more free stuff for regular people.

@QuanSai @sriramk That's a fine business model, but the economic result is that the managers of the game lose the ability to get more from people who *want* more, and the people who *want more* lose the ability to pay more.

In-game purchases are ways of getting value from surplus. (green area) https://t.co/KmqPKbGAAJ

@QuanSai @sriramk So you're saying people buy a complete game and that game does not change, and/or, they pay a subscription fee that covers ongoing development, but beyond those ongoing server costs, they don't have micro-transactions or other in-game purchases at all. Right?
@rocketgirlNFT If the market gets too bear, $500K and I'll audit your NFT scam. Including tornado send & recipient addresses, CEX offramp plan, etc.üòÇ
@QuanSai @sriramk I'll need to think about that, is there anything (consenting & non-exploitive) that should explicitly not be monetized in your view?

Crazy to know I have all the skills needed to make $10M+ on an NFT scam with < 2% chance of getting doxxed and all the network analysis skills to avoid laundering getting detected, and too many morals to do it.

@QuanSai @sriramk The attention devil gives nothing back though. YT is pretty much the only platform to my knowledge that gives a significant % of revenue to creators. TikTok & the rest is paltry for bottom 95-99%. Web3 fixes this.

Although yes- more fundamentally, is attention a humane currency?

@sriramk The only reason FAANG & big consulting firms had world-changing talent wasting away on ad optimization was there wasn't a better way to make money besides selling your soul to the attention devil. Now we finally have a build good stuff => money pipeline. They stand no chance.

@xenes1s I guess my point is, yes to everything you said, but I'm optimistic that we're headed in the right direction. These coins can all flip a switch and make their tokens actually accrue value and then entire industry would 10x within a year.

@xenes1s There are some really successful primitives though. 

Stablecoin bearing CDPs (Maker)
Generalized CDPs (AAVE)
Yield APIs (Yearn, Compound)
Self rebalancing indexes (Balancer)
infinite & concentrated AMMs (Uniswap)
IL insured AMMs (Bancor)
Decentralized stables (FRAX, AMPL)

@kermankohli They can join @charliedao_eth - lots to learn, plenty of potential projects, we just ask for participation and a few pro bono hours each month. They don't have to do 100% switch immediately. Get their feet wet with friends.

@mmaatt78 @RyanSAdams Just like people use credit, debit, apps, crypto, and cash- there will be crypto coins that have different requirements, coded governance/admin, etc., and use cases. Fedcoin might be how we pay taxes. FXcoin may be how governments pay each other, etc.

@mmaatt78 @RyanSAdams translation: there will be a crypto SWIFT where the coins can blacklist addresses (USDT already does this for hacks, blocking the transfer function for hacker addresses). The regulators will always have a permissioned system, it just won't be the monopoly for all value.

@mmaatt78 @RyanSAdams That world won't exist. People have a spectrum of trust in government and that transfers to a spectrum of desires when it comes to money (e.g. FDIC insured deposit accounts). We should expect stablecoins that comply with AML (e.g., USDT and USDC) to grow accordingly.

@mellamomark_eth Ive never considered myself a thought leader or creator. I just like yelling into the void. Too much gamification leads to lower quality experience, but at the same time, I do see how there are personal benefits to a large following as a signal to others with large followings.
@mellamomark_eth I am mostly doxxed, easy to ID, but I wouldn't do that so explicitly. Opens yourself up to a lot of attack vectors after you start seeing success.

thorough arithm‚Ä¶
@SeanSemola I'll pay $300 in gas fees for an NFT before I pay $3 to twitter to verify my NFT.
@WNTRjon @danielgothits Ok, 0.08 ETH, and he matches the 2.2M. Don't miss the forest for the trees. He could have sold any amount of collectibles and made them *liquid*.

@GeoffAWilliams @edzitron Interoperability is how you get network effects that make you a default "way of doing something".

For something like money natively on the internet, we should expect multiple systems (just like we have multiple messaging systems) - but there will still be defaults & winners.
@GeoffAWilliams @edzitron Can you name the most successful emailing system that doesn't use SMTP?

@GeoffAWilliams @edzitron So in this hypothetical, Gmail, Outlook, Apple Mail, could all just agree to use Ethereum as the database of address <=> amount, just as they all use SMTP & DNS as the database for email address <=> email message.

@GeoffAWilliams @edzitron Ethereum has enough participating computers w/ enough historical "blocks" proving participants were credibly neutral to earn the trust of groups who want to offer digital property mgmt to their customers, but don't want to build all the infrastructure themselves.

@GeoffAWilliams @edzitron But would Apple build on top of Google Pay? Would Microsoft? 

No. 

Could they all hypothetically agree to use Paypal? or JP Morgan Chase? or another 3rd party to manage that database for all of them? 

Good luck w/ that.

@GeoffAWilliams @edzitron Gmail could wake up tomorrow and say, hey, you can send us $5 and we'll note it in our database next to your email. And you just let us know if you want to withdraw it or transfer it to another gmail address okay!

Some people would opt into this. (Google Pay lol).

@GeoffAWilliams @edzitron Where property could be anything people agree as valuable. For example- Ether the currency used to pay for the network. Or example a receipt saying "good for $1 dollar at [bank X]" issued by bank X where a sufficient number of people use/trust bank X that can confirm the $1.

@GeoffAWilliams @edzitron Outlook, Apple Mail, Gmail don't need to create their own messaging system and then have some 3rd party handle interoperating and translation the messages to other systems. They just all share SMTP.

Blockchain enables SMTP for *any* data, including property records.

@GeoffAWilliams @edzitron This is because a network of computers voluntarily participate to run software (e.g., the go-ethereum client) where any arbitrary compatible code can be run and outputs from past code be accessed.

This allows any competitive groups to collaborate where doing so benefits them.

@GeoffAWilliams @edzitron The addresses still rely on DNS though - which is a 3rd party. And the content itself is duplicable (see: chain spam). 

Blockchains enable arbitrarily complex databases to be shared. Instead of DNS where it is IP Address <=> human readable name. It's ANY address <=> data pair.

@GeoffAWilliams @edzitron 3/ if competitors can create/ trust a 3rd party for managing shared scarcity then it all works. But this is contentious and rarely credibly neutral (see: any association where big tech is disproportionate funder).

But protocols like HTTP, TCP/IP, SMTP don't have this problem.

NFT Design mockup for upcoming protocol. You lock in ETH for some time, get paid frETH upfront, & get this NFT as a key. Sell it as P2P bond or treat it like a CD. At maturity, you get your ETH back and keep all the frETH you minted. Unlock early & pay penalties to FRZ stakers. https://t.co/aGJzoYQgIW

(3) This is not good and I think access to stable money is a human right
(4) blockchains do this: Credibly neutral, decentralized, permissonless blah blah blah.

@GeoffAWilliams @edzitron The options are: 
(1) Governments loosen up capital controls.
(2) Fintech companies disobey governments to bring fair money to all.
(3) We continue with some people aren't allowed to have stable money b/c they were born wrong.
(4) Embed property rights into the internet.
